div.h1: All Official District Parent Communication Regarding HISD COVID-19 Closure (newest listed first)

h1.aria-label: April 20, 2020 @ 1:30 PM - Update from the Superintendent on Closure & Priorities
h1.span: April 20, 2020 @ 1:30 PM - Update from the Superintendent on Closure & Priorities

div.p:
Dear Hornet Parents:
At noon on Friday, April 17, Governor Greg Abbott extended the closure of all Texas schools for the remainder of the 2019-2020 school year; however, remote learning will continue in Huntsville ISD and in districts across the state. While I am disappointed that we will not be able to close out the school year in our traditional way, we must follow the directives issued by the governor so we can safely come back together in the future. Here are some of our key priorities in Huntsville ISD as we continue to navigate the challenges brought about by COVID-19:
Remote Learning Opportunities: Although our classrooms are empty, we are committed to supporting student learning through the dedication of our teachers, campus administrators, campus support staff, and instructional personnel, as they connect with their students and provide instructional support. The Huntsville ISD Hornet Instructional Assignments program will continue to be enriched and enhanced each week to keep our students sharp and prepared for promotion. We fully realize the burden placed on families during this difficult time. As I have communicated before, our goal is to prepare our students and get everyone across the finish line. Regardless of the challenges you may face with technology, time available to help your children with schoolwork, or other difficulties adjusting to this new method of learning, our team stands ready to help everyone adapt and succeed. Working directly with your teachers and campus administrators is the best way to resolve any issues you may have during this period of remote instruction.
HISD Meal Program: We will continue to provide meals as we have since the onset of this event. Our employees in food service and transportation have been amazing throughout the crisis, serving the community every way possible!
Class of 2020 Seniors: Because of COVID-19, Sam Houston State University will not be hosting activities on campus until July, including their own graduation ceremony. As a result, we have secured our usual venue at SHSU for our graduation ceremony on Saturday, July 25 at 10:00 AM. Additional information about graduation and other Senior 2020 activities has been communicated to senior students and parents by our HHS Principal, Bill Roberts, and we will provide the entire community with more information in the near future.
Grading, GPA and semester averages: Now that it is certain we will not be returning to face to face instruction this school year, we will finalize plans regarding grade calculations and communicate this to you soon. In the meantime, continue to encourage your children to complete remote assignments.
Student and staff items: We will be developing and communicating a plan for staff and students to return to campus in order to safely retrieve any remaining personal belongings.
UIL: In response to the extended closure of Texas schools, the UIL has suspended all practices and contests (extracurricular academic, athletic and music) for the remainder of the 2019-2020 school year.
On behalf of the entire Huntsville ISD staff, we miss you and look forward to the time when we can safely be together again. Look for regular updates as we continue to navigate this unprecedented event together and continue Building Champions in Huntsville ISD.
Sincerely,
Scott Sheppard, Ed.D.
Superintendent
Huntsville ISD

p.a: Click Here to View Spanish Verision of Superintendent's Letter

h1.aria-label: April 8, 2020 @ 3:45 PM - Important Information for Parents re: Hornet Instruction
h1.span: April 8, 2020 @ 3:45 PM - Important Information for Parents re: Hornet Instruction

p.span: We trust this communication finds you well and safe. This has been a challenging time for our nation as well as our community but together this situation will strengthen our resolve to bounce back in an awesome way. As you have read, the district will now remain closed until at least May 4th. If you recall the district did a first phase launch of providing resources and optional student work in the form of packets and grade level online resources the week of March 23

. The purpose of the first phase launch, or Hornet Instructional Activities, was to encourage our students to continue learning at home and provide opportunities for teachers to reconnect with students.

Beginning Monday, April 13, we will begin the second phase of the Huntsville ISD online learning platform. All online content instruction will take place through our learning management system, Google Classroom. Google Classroom is a system that enables teachers to create an online classroom area in which they can manage all the documents that their students need, virtually interact with students

and send and receive assignments online. During the second phase of implementation students will be given assignments that will be graded. This means once students receive an assignment, they will be required to complete it during the time frame provided by the teacher and submit it back to the teacher for a numerical
or alpha grade. Grades will be assigned according to district grading guidelines.

Principals have been given specific direction and information about the second phase and will continue to share with their staff members as they have been. Teachers will be communicating directly with families and students with specific information regarding their classes and required lessons for students. Resources in Google Classroom will be updated frequently for families to access additional activities to support the lessons assigned by their teachers. Please make every effort to monitor your child’s work, so learning is on-going during the district closure.

Even though campuses remain closed and not accessible, learning opportunities will still be available. If a student is in need of technology you may contact the campus for assistance and support. As we begin this second phase of the journey, please know you are not alone as the Huntsville ISD family is here to support you.

br.span: The 3
rd
nine week grading cycle for elementary and intermediate campuses ended on March 20
th
. Since there were more days left in the grading cycle, 3
rd
nine week report cards for Pre-k through 6
th
grades will be distributed at the end of April.
For secondary campuses grades 7-12, the grading period ends on April 9
th

. Due to the timeframe students have been out of school, and to allow adequate time to close out the six week grading cycle, we will also delay the release of secondary report cards until the end of April. This process will allow time for our teachers to capture assignments and allow the district to release report cards at the same time in our Home Access Center (HAC).
br.strong: How are teachers continuing to provide support and new learning? For example, will teachers provide pre-recorded videos, check-ins, run an online classroom etc.?
br.span: Teachers will provide support and new learning through the Google Classroom portal, individual
student packets (as needed), pre-recorded videos and by creating learning modules.
br.strong: How will students in each grade level and content area access the instructional
br.span: Majority of students (PK-12) will access instructional materials through the Google Classroom
platform. If there is a family, based upon parent communication and documented with the
campus, that has no access to technology, campuses will work individually with the family.
br.strong: How and when will teachers be available to students and families to answer
br.span: Teacher schedules will be set by campus administration and communicated to families through
the campus’s normal mode of communication.
br.strong: How will teachers continue to monitor student progress?
br.span: Teachers will continue to monitor student progress through email, phone calls and electronic
assignment return portals.
br.strong: How will Special Education services and supports be implemented?
br.span: ARDs will continue to be held virtually during the closure. The assessment team will keep the

campus ARD calendars updated and communicate with campus staff as needed as well as parents. Related services are being implemented in a combination of tele therapy, Google Classroom and hands-on materials.

Parents of students served by Special Education and Section 504 services are encouraged to continue engaging with your campus and district contact person to support your student’s individualized needs. If you have Special Education or 504 questions, please call 936-435-6970 between 8 am and 4 pm on Monday-Thursday for assistance or to arrange for a meeting opportunity.
br.strong: What tools are available to support English Language Learners?
br.span: For bilingual students in PK-4th grade, lessons will be provided in both English and Spanish. Bilingual students in grades 5-6 will continue receiving instruction in a blended format that includes Proximity Learning, as well as instruction and support through Google Classroom. ESL students in all grade levels will receive support based on their language needs. Teachers will provide support for these students through their Google Classroom. District bilingual staff will be available to provide interpreting services in Spanish/English. If you or your student are in need of this support, please contact your child’s school or you may contact the Bilingual/ESL Coordinator, Ana Thomas, at athomas@huntsville-isd.org or 936-435-6338.
br.strong: What if my student does not have a computer at home?
br.span: On a limited basis Chromebooks will be provided. Bear in mind, the district does not have enough Chromebooks for each individual child in the district but in some instances multiple students in the same family may be able to take advantage of sharing a device.
br.strong: How can I complete work without the internet?
br.span: In our area numerous options may be available at minimal or no cost. Sudden Link is offering free internet for people living in their coverage area. Numerous cell phone carriers are waiving data limits which allow you to turn your phone into a WiFi hotspot at no extra charge. Huntsville ISD has WiFi signals at all of our campuses and facilities so families can come to the campus and access WiFi for free outside. When using this option be sure to adhere to the social distancing order. It would be best if students and families remain in their vehicle while connecting to WiFi.
br.strong: Will the at-home learning work be graded?
br.span: Yes. Students are expected to participate in the at-home learning assignments and the assignments will be graded.

Our goal is to not cause or create any additional stress on families but understand there may be some minor issues as we implement the roll out of this plan. We will work with you and our students to ensure they have what they need to do the work and be successful in the process.

If you have a question about any of this information feel free to contact your child’s teacher or campus principal. If your question is about a lesson or assignment, please contact your child’s teacher through Google Classroom or via email.

During this time of transition and change we truly appreciate your patience, support and understanding as we provide virtual learning opportunities for all of our students. As we continue to exercise social distancing remember we are still united together in heart, mind and spirit.
Marcus D. Forney
Assistant Superintendent for Curriculum & Instruction

div.em: Please watch this video message from Superintendent, Dr. Sheppard about COVID-19, Huntsville ISD and our Hornet Family: https://youtu.be/He2BZxZJ92g.
For all news and updates during the HISD COVID-19 closure, please visit the HISD website: https://www.huntsville-isd.org/coronavirus.

h1.aria-label: March 31, 2020 @ 2:50 PM - A Message from the Superintendent - School Closure Extended Thru May 1
h1.span: March 31, 2020 @ 2:50 PM - A Message from the Superintendent - School Closure Extended Thru May 1

div.p:
Tuesday, March 31, 2020
Dear Huntsville ISD Parents, Staff, and Community:
If you are like me, it is still a little hard to believe we are in our current situation as a worldwide community. As the COVID-19 pandemic raged on, two days ago President Trump extended federal social distancing guidelines until the end of April. Moments ago, Governor Abbott issued an executive order closing Texas schools until May 4. In Huntsville ISD, we agree with these steps which are in line with our continual priority to keep our students, staff and community safe; therefore, Huntsville ISD is extending closure of our campuses through Friday, May 1, with a possible return date of Monday, May 4.
Learning at home is the new normal for now. It is vital for students and parents to understand that school is not over for the year just because we are physically closed and unable to meet face to face. Even if we are able to reopen campuses in May to wrap up loose ends, we must operate from the mindset that we can no longer wait to cover new material and finish course content. While the state has canceled STAAR and EOC tests for the year, they have not backed off on expectations for students to demonstrate mastery of this year’s learning objectives. Teachers have been in contact with students, work has been available online and in limited paper packets, and of course, this has looked different for elementary and secondary students. In the coming days, you will hear more about our strengthened educational plans during closure and a shift from optional work meant for review, to required assignments designed to finish courses. We will work with each individual child and family in our district to help them finish the year strong!
Our promises to our school community are simple. Above all, we will make decisions that protect your health and safety. As for the education, promotion, and graduation of our Hornets, we will make certain every student has ample opportunities to demonstrate they have learned the content of their current courses so they can move forward. For our seniors, the goal is to graduate on time. For underclassmen, the goal is to successfully pass every class and prepare for next year. For our Pre-K through middle school kids, the goal is for every student to be fully prepared and promoted to the next grade. To reach these goals, teachers, parents, and students must work together to make learning happen while campuses are closed.
In addition to our increasing efforts to deliver instructional materials through both high tech and low tech means, Huntsville ISD will continue to serve our kids and community through our free meal programs that have been very successful and expanding since closure began. Communication from your campus administration and individual teachers will likely increase as our physical closure continues, and you should also continue to check the Huntsville ISD Coronavirus Information Update webpage: www.huntsville-isd.org/coronavirus and parent emails for the most up to date information.
As we have reminded you throughout this crisis, please continue to keep general health precautions in mind, as outlined by the Center for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC): www.cdc.gov/coronavirus and the Texas Department of State Health Services (TxDSHS): www.dshs.state.tx.us/coronavirus.
Thank you for your ongoing patience and understanding as we navigate this unprecedented event. Do your best to focus on the now and the known, and we will continually adjust to meet the needs of our community as things change. Together, we will get through this and come out stronger as we never lose sight of our focus on Building Champions in Huntsville ISD.
Sincerely,

Scott Sheppard, Ed.D.
Superintendent
Huntsville ISD
#BUILDINGCHAMPIONS

p.a: Click Here to View Spanish Verision of Superintendent's Letter

h1.aria-label: March 30, 2020 @ 7:00 PM - Important Updates for Families/Change to Bus Meal Delivery
h1.span: March 30, 2020 @ 7:00 PM - Important Updates for Families/Change to Bus Meal Delivery

div.p:
Huntsville ISD Parents/Guardians,
Please see the following updates from the district...
MEALS:
The HISD "Grab & Go" Lunch distribution continues this week on Monday through Friday from 11 AM to 1 PM at all campuses CURBSIDE AND via the Green Hornet Food Bus following the schedule for its 5 designated public locations and times.
Please note there are several CHANGES for the Multi-Meal Pack Bus Delivery plan for TOMORROW, Tuesday, March 31.

Starting at 2:00 PM, Huntsville ISD Buses will run the MORNING route (includes all AM & PM stops) delivering multi-meal packs to children ages 0-18. Buses will START delivering from the farthest point on the route FIRST. Each TUESDAY pack will contain a variety of non-perishable food items appropriate for 5 meals for a child. Any child can participate so long as they are present at one of the stops on the bus route.
Additionally, Huntsville ISD will have 1 bus distributing packs at the 4 common locations designated below at the set time shown. If you live in one of these designated areas, this will be the ONLY opportunity to receive a multi-meal pack as there will NOT be another bus routed to your area on Tuesday.
2:00 PM - Estill & Nance Circle (Watkins-Clark Addition-HHA)
2:20 PM - Tanglewood Mobile Home Park
2:40 PM - Ridgewood West Apts (near the playground)
3:00 PM - Little "L" Mobile Home Park (1658 SH 75N)
**Buses will not begin routes until 2 PM and they will following their regular MORNING routes. Please allow a window of time for delivery to your regular stop. Understand the bus may pass by you on its way to the farthest point of its route where it will begin and work its way back along the route to you. And if you live in one of these 4 designated common locations listed above, the time listed will be your ONLY opportunity to receive a pack.
An updated flyer is attached. For the latest Meal Information during the COVID-19 Closure, please visit: https://www.huntsville-isd.org/coronavirus/lunch
INSTRUCTIONAL OPPORTUNITIES:
Additional and optional instructional activities and resources for our Hornets were launched last week with activities available in both digital and paper form. The Hornet Instructional Activities links for Elementary and Secondary are available on the district website at the bottom of the page: https://www.huntsville-isd.org/coronavirus/instruction
Elementary campuses will post new instructional activities online each Wednesday and have new paper packets available on Wednesday in the tubs in front of each Elementary school. For information specific to Secondary campus, please visit their campus websites, Google Classrooms and Teacher webpages. Parents and students should continue to monitor school email accounts frequently for any district, campus, or teacher communications.
TECHNOLOGY SURVEY:
If you have not already completed the quick Technology Survey sent out on March 22, please do. Your response will help us understand your child’s current access to technology so we can better serve them during the COVID-19 closure.
English survey link: https://forms.gle/AJHwtEbgECj4Dzs76
Spanish survey link: https://forms.gle/5dSCuKevdCipnHDE6
LIMITED PHONE ACCESS:
Campuses and the Hawkins Administration Buildings have limited personnel available on Monday thru Thursday to answer general phone calls:
Campuses from 8:00 AM to 10:00 AM
Hawkins Administration from 10:00 AM to 1:00 PM
*All buildings will remain CLOSED to the public during this time according to the declaration of a state of emergency established by Walker County.
SOCIAL MEDIA:
We encourage families to LIKE and FOLLOW us on Facebook where the district and all campuses have an official page. Campuses are busy sharing a lot of great and fun information for our students and families there.

Please continue to monitor the Huntsville ISD Coronavirus Information Update webpage: https://www.huntsville-isd.org/coronavirus for the most up to date information. Additionally, continue to keep general health precautions in mind, including proper hand washing, social distancing and other preventative steps outlined by the Center for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC): https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus and the Texas Department of State Health Services (TxDSHS): https://www.dshs.state.tx.us/coronavirus.
Please stay safe and healthy! And tell your Hornets that we miss them very much!!!

h1.aria-label: March 22, 2020 @ 8:30 PM - Important Updates for Huntsville ISD Families
h1.span: March 22, 2020 @ 8:30 PM - Important Updates for Huntsville ISD Families

div.p: Please see the following district updates regarding Meals, Instructional Opportunities, Technology Survey and limited Phone Access through the current closure.

Free Grab & Go Meals
The HISD No-Cost Lunch Program for all Huntsville area children (ages 0-18) has expanded! Beginning Monday, March 23, free “Grab & Go” lunches will be available Monday thru Friday via the Green Hornet Bus AND Curbside at ALL HISD Campuses. The Green Hornet will follow a set time schedule distributing at 5 public bus stops. Campus CURBSIDE will be from 11:00 AM to 1:00 PM. Please stay in your vehicle at curbside sites. Limit number of people at each bus stop to 10 or less. All meal sacks will include lunch items for the day and breakfast items for the next. Additionally, Huntsville ISD Buses will run regular homebound (PM) routes each TUESDAY afternoon delivering meal packs to children filled with 5 days’ worth of non-perishable food items. Buses will run approximately 2 hours earlier than normal afternoon route delivery times. Any child can participate so long as they are at a designated bus route stop. According to TDA rules, children MUST be present in order to be eligible to receive free meals. See district website for all meal details and schedule: https://www.huntsville-isd.org/coronavirus/lunch.

Instructional Opportunities
We recognize the significant impact an extended closure has on the entire community, especially for families who depend on the district for critical services. While our classrooms are empty, our work on behalf of children continues. During the closure, online educational resources are available to families which will provide continuity in our students’ learning. These general educational resources are available online for elementary and secondary levels. The District will launch additional and optional instructional activities and resources for our Hornets beginning this week in both digital and paper form. Monitor your parent/student email accounts and the district website: https://www.huntsville-isd.org/coronavirus/instruction for instructions to access once available.

Technology Survey
To better serve our students during this COVID-19 closure, please complete this very quick Technology Survey to help us understand your child’s current access to technology.
English survey link: https://forms.gle/AJHwtEbgECj4Dzs76
Spanish survey link: https://forms.gle/5dSCuKevdCipnHDE6

Phone Access
Starting Monday, March 23, all campuses and the Hawkins Administration Buildings will have limited personnel available on Monday thru Thursday to answer phone calls:
Campuses from 8:00 AM to 10:00 AM
Hawkins Administration from 10:00 AM to 1:00 PM

p.em: *All buildings will remain CLOSED to the public during this time according to the declaration of a state of emergency established by Walker County.

div.p:
Please continue to check the Huntsville ISD Coronavirus Information Update webpage: https://www.huntsville-isd.org/coronavirus for the most up to date information. Additionally, please continue to keep general health precautions in mind, including proper hand washing and other preventative steps outlined by the Center for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC): https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus and the Texas Department of State Health Services (TxDSHS): https://www.dshs.state.tx.us/coronavirus.
Huntsville ISD Schools remain closed through at least Friday, April 3. We hope to be able to resume normal operations on Monday, April 6. We miss our Hornets! Please continue to stay safe & healthy!!!

h1.aria-label: March 17, 2020 @ 8:35 PM Update from the Superintendent Regarding Extended School Closure
h1.span: March 17, 2020 @ 8:35 PM Update from the Superintendent Regarding Extended School Closure

div.h1: March 17, 2020 @ 8:35 pm - Update Regarding Extended School Closure

div.p: Dear Huntsville ISD Parents, Staff, and Community:

We understand this has been a challenging time for our community as many balance career, family and childcare. As you know, the information regarding the spread of COVID-19 has been evolving daily, even hourly, as reported cases in Texas have gradually increased. The CDC has already recommended social distancing protocols, and is now asking the public to comply with directives to limit gatherings to 10 people or less and implement multi-week school closures to help mitigate the spread of the virus. With these priorities in mind, Huntsville ISD will be postponing the reopening of our schools until at least Monday, April 6, 2020.

Huntsville ISD’s Lunch program, which started today with 5 daily stops by the Green Hornet food truck and “Grab and Go” curbside service at Huntsville High School, will continue throughout this extended closure for all Huntsville area children ages 1-18, free of charge. We know parents have a number of questions about instruction, access to technology, waivers, exemptions, graduation, the needs of specific student groups, and other school topics. These matters are all being addressed and planned for with details forthcoming. Please continue to check the Huntsville ISD Coronavirus Information Update webpage: www.huntsville-isd.org/coronavirus and parent emails for the most up to date information.

Additionally, please continue to keep general health precautions in mind, including proper hand washing and other preventative steps outlined by the Center for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC): www.cdc.gov/coronavirus and the Texas Department of State Health Services (TxDSHS): www.dshs.state.tx.us/coronavirus.
Thank you for your ongoing patience and understanding as we navigate these unprecedented circumstances together and do our best to protect our Huntsville ISD school community.
Sincerely,

img.br:
Scott Sheppard, Ed.D.
Superintendent
Huntsville ISD

div.p: Dear Huntsville ISD Families:

The impact of COVID-19 continues to be an ever changing event for our community, state and nation. I have been in constant contact with Texas Education Agency officials, as well as local and state health and emergency management agencies throughout the weekend. This morning, I met with members of our district administrative team to review the latest information and continue working to serve our students to the best of our ability during these unprecedented times. Rest assured, we will take care of our staff and students in Huntsville ISD, both in terms of health and safety, and in terms of meeting the academic needs of our students. Here are a few important updates for you:

li.strong: Beginning Tuesday, March 17 through Friday, March 20 HISD will provide a no-cost Lunch Distribution for Children ages 1-18 (details below)

ul.li:
According to TDA Rules, Children must be present to be eligible to receive the free meal; this is not dependent on where the student is enrolled.
Green Hornet Food Bus:
The Green Hornet Food Bus will distribute “Grab & Go” Lunches at 5 designated public sites listed below. Lunches will be distributed for a limited amount of time at each site before moving to the next location.
10:45 AM - Cogan's Grove Subdivision (FM 1696)
11:30 AM - YMCA (Old Houston Rd)
11:55 AM - Boys & Girls Club of Walker County (MLK Dr)
12:20 PM - University Heights Baptist Church (Sycamore Ave)
1:00 PM - Riverside Baptist Church
To avoid creating large crowds at each bus stop location, please help us limit the number of people gathered by leaving the premises as soon as your child receives their lunch.
Curbside at Huntsville High School:
“Grab & Go” Lunches will also be distributed CURBSIDE at Huntsville High School from 11:00 - 1:00 PM. Please turn onto Hornet Way and drive to the far back parking lot of the campus (behind the gym/commons areas) which is located at the rear of the campus. Please remain in your vehicles the entire time and use the Bus Loading Zone (along covered sidewalk) and wait for the HISD Child Nutrition Staff to bring the number of children’s meals needed to your vehicle.
UIL Contests (see https://www.uiltexas.org/):
All UIL events have been suspended by the state UIL office thru March 29.
The UIL anticipates completing the competitive season for academics, athletics and fine arts later this spring.

We recognize the importance of continuing your child’s academic progress during this unscheduled break from school. Our team is working hard to publish extended learning resources, which will be available this week. Please monitor the district website, teacher webpages and Google Classrooms for updated information as it becomes available.
Governor Greg Abbott announced today that he has waived the State of Texas Assessments of Academic Readiness (STAAR) testing requirements for the 2019-2020 school year.
Additional information will be forthcoming from the State.
Refer to the dedicated Coronavirus (COVID-19) webpage on the district website at https//www.huntsville-isd.org/coronavirus.

div.p: I will be updating you throughout the week via email. As of now, we are on a day-to-day decision making schedule, but we will make every effort to publish our return to school date as soon as possible. As always, I am proud of the way our staff, students, parents and community have responded in difficult times. I am grateful to be your superintendent. Our focus on Building Champions is stronger than ever!

Please stay safe,
Scott Sheppard, Ed.D.
Superintendent
Huntsville ISD

h1.aria-label: March 13, 2020 A Message from the Superintendent re: School Closure
h1.span: March 13, 2020 A Message from the Superintendent re: School Closure

div.p:
Dear Huntsville ISD Parents/Guardians,
In response to growing concerns and continued spread of the Novel Coronavirus, or COVID-19, all Huntsville ISD campuses will remain CLOSED from March 16-20, 2020. All school activities and events will be canceled during this time. This closure affects all before and after school programming, all athletic and extracurricular activities, practices, banquets and competitions as well as weekend events.
We understand the burden school closure places on our parents and community; however, this decision was made out of an abundance of caution to assist public health authorities with efforts to halt the spread of this virus. Please continue to keep general health precautions in mind, including proper hand washing and other preventative steps outlined by the Center for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC): www.cdc.gov/coronavirus and the Texas Department of State Health Services (TxDSHS): www.dshs.state.tx.us/coronavirus.
We will continue to monitor this rapidly evolving situation and keep you informed as needed. For more coronavirus pandemic information, resources or updates, please visit the coronavirus page on the district website: www.huntsville-isd.org/coronavirus. We will send out a parent notification by Friday, March 20 to communicate if our schools will remain closed or reopen on March 23. We appreciate your patience and understanding as we make these decisions in the best interest of Huntsville ISD students and staff.

Sincerely,
Scott Sheppard, Ed.D.
Superintendent
Huntsville ISD

h1.aria-label: March 12, 2020 Superintendent Message to Huntsville ISD Parents & Staff
h1.span: March 12, 2020 Superintendent Message to Huntsville ISD Parents & Staff

div.p: Dear Fellow Hornets:

As you are aware, the situation regarding COVID-19 continues to be very fluid in the Greater Houston area and across the state. I want to assure you that despite our schools being closed this week for spring break, I have been monitoring the situation through daily calls and emails with local, state and federal officials.
I expect more information from the Texas Education Agency and other state officials by tomorrow, so expect an update from me later on Friday.

The safety, security and health of our students and staff is our number one priority. We will follow the guidance of local, state and federal health agencies in making the best decisions for Huntsville ISD.

p.br:
Sincerely,
Scott Sheppard, Ed.D.
Superintendent
Huntsville ISD

h1.aria-label: March 5, 2020 Superintendent Letter to Huntsville ISD families
h1.span: March 5, 2020 Superintendent Letter to Huntsville ISD families

div.p: Dear Huntsville ISD Families,

With our Spring Break closure scheduled for next week, I wanted to take the opportunity to update you on the district’s efforts surrounding the growing concern of the respiratory illness caused by the 2019 novel (new) coronavirus (COVID-19). Huntsville ISD is aware of the coronavirus outbreak and is closely monitoring the events. We are following the guidance of our local health officials, the Texas Department of State Health Services (Texas DSHS) and the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC). While these trustworthy health officials believe the risk to our school community is low at this time, we will continue to track the situation and follow their direction as this situation develops and make plans accordingly for the health and safety of our students, staff and community.

The 2019 novel coronavirus is a virus that causes respiratory illness in people and can spread from person-to-person. At this time, persons considered at risk are those with travel to China, or those in close contact with persons infected with the novel coronavirus. The coronavirus is not currently wide spread in communities in the United States, and there are no confirmed cases here in Walker County or the surrounding area. Updated information from the CDC on coronavirus in the United States can be found at: https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/index.html. The most recent information about coronavirus in Texas can be found at: https://dshs.texas.gov/coronavirus/.

Much information is still being learned about this newly emerged virus. Based on the current information, health officials are recommending local communities and schools should take the same simple preventive actions to help prevent the spread of this coronavirus as we do to prevent the spread of other everyday illnesses like the common cold or the flu:

ul.li: Wash your hands often with soap and water for at least 20 seconds. If soap and water are not available, use an alcohol-based hand sanitizer.
Avoid touching your eyes, nose, and mouth with unwashed hands.
Cover your mouth and nose with the inside of your elbow when you cough or sneeze.
Clean and disinfect frequently touched objects and surfaces.
Avoid close contact with people who are sick.

li.strong: Stay home when you are sick.

div.p: The coronavirus is spread through the air when an infected person coughs or sneezes, much in the same way the flu and other respiratory viruses are spread. Symptoms can be fever, cough, or difficulty breathing. While a new type of illness can be scary, we can protect our students, employees, and the broader community by using these preventative steps that also protect people from other types of respiratory viruses. Our teachers, school nurses, and staff have been working carefully to encourage these simple and effective habits of frequent handwashing, covering every cough or sneeze, and cleaning classroom tables/surfaces frequently. This is important not just to help prevent the spread of coronavirus but to help prevent the spread of other infections that can lead to student illness and absences.

The Huntsville ISD custodial staff has increased cleaning frequency since early fall in response to expanding flu cases. Using hospital-grade products, they have enhanced their efforts this month to disinfect all classrooms and common contact surfaces nightly to help offset the spread of all communicable illnesses. Over spring break, additional steps to deep clean and disinfect will be taken. When we return from the break, HISD Transportation will begin a daily routine treatment of disinfecting buses following each route. As a reminder, we are still in the midst of cold and flu season, and it’s important for all families to take preventative measures to safeguard themselves. We have shared additional links to helpful health related resources on the district website at: https://www.huntsville-isd.org/health.

Thank you for your support of our district, our schools, our students, and our teachers and staff. I hope you have a very safe, healthy and restful break.
Sincerely,
Scott Sheppard, Ed.D.
Superintendent
Huntsville ISD

p.span: Huntsville ISD will provide Free Lunch Distribution to ALL Huntsville area Children (ages 0-18 years old) during the COVID-19 Closure.

Distribution opportunites are available via the Green Hornet Food Bus as well as CURBISDE at all HISD campuses except Huntsville Intermediate. Meal sacks will include lunch items for that day as well as breakfast items for the next.

span.em: Additionally, on TUESDAYS HISD Buses will be delivering multi-meal packs to children. Starting at 2 PM HISD Buses will follow the regular MORNING ROUTE (stopping at all regular AM & PM stops) with the exception of 4 designated common locations where there will be delivery at a set time. If you are not familiar with HISD Bus routes you should go to one of the common locations listed. To see schedule with locations and times click link below.

p.span: Meal Schedule with all Locations & Times. (*Per TDA Rules, the children must be present to be eligible to receive free meals.)

div.h1: Instructional Opportunities for use during COVID-19 Closure

p.span: We recognize the importance of continuing your child’s academic progress during this unscheduled break from school.

Extended learning resources have been created for use during the COVID-19 school closure. The launch of our Hornet Instructional Opportunities started with Phase 1 - Hornet Instructional Assignments for student review and enrichment followed by Phase 2 - Hornet Instructional Assignments for new instruction and grades taken for assignments beginning the week of April 13. All online content instruction will take place through our learning management system, Google Classroom. Links with details for Elementary and Secondary are available at: https://www.huntsville-isd.org/coronavirus/instruction

span.em: Please frequently check parent/student school emails (check SPAM folder, too) and monitor the district website, teacher webpages and Google Classrooms for updated information as it becomes available throughout the closure.

p.span: Parents: Please take a few seconds to complete this quick Technology Survey so we can understand your child’s current access to technology. The information will help us to better meet their Technology needs for Instructional purposes moving forward during the extended COVID-19 school closure!

br.span:
English survey link: https://forms.gle/AJHwtEbgECj4Dzs76
Spanish survey link: https://forms.gle/5dSCuKevdCipnHDE6

h1.aria-label: Free Public WiFi Access & Hornet Hotspots
h1.span: Free Public WiFi Access & Hornet Hotspots

div.p: The wireless network inside of our campuses & buildings reaches beyond our walls & is accessible outside.
Therefore, you can access HISD Public wireless network from outside any of our campuses or buildings.

Please maintain social distancing requirements by staying at least 6 ft apart & do not form a crowd. Best practices dictate that you stay in your vehicle during your visit. We hope to continue this service during the COVID-19 experience.
We reserve the right to ask people to disperse & will discontinue this service, if we feel it is jeopardizing the health & safety of others.

hr.p: Additionally, many of our campuses have a designated external location with covered place to sit for the public to access the internet over a WiFi connection or "Hornet Hotspot."
Each of these designated areas has a posted sign that looks like the Hornet image shown below.

ul.li: Gibbs PreK Center - picnic table at the back of the school
Huntsville Elementary - awning in the back of the school
Samuel W. Houston Elementary - awning by playground
Scott Johnson Elementary - awning at the back of the school
Stewart Elementary - courtyard
Huntsville Intermediate - area outside of the library
Technology Department - awning at the intersection of Avenue M and 7th Street

div.em: These HISD locations provide FREE public wireless where our access is broadcast OUTSIDE the buildings in designated areas.

div.p:
Internet Providers in the Huntsville Texas area and their offerings: Please check these sites as the information is constantly changing.
Suddenlink:
Free Internet for 60 days. Click the link to view.
Suddenlink (also know as Altice)
Sprint info:
Sprint
Follows FCC Agreement, provides unlimited data to existing customers, and , starting Tuesday, 3/17/2020, will allow all handsets to enable hot-spots for 60 days at no extra charge.
T-Mobile Info:
https://www.t-mobile.com/brand/ongoing-updates-covid-19
Starting now - ALL current T-Mobile and Metro by T-Mobile customers who have plans with data will have unlimited smartphone data for the next 60 days (excluding roaming).
AT&T Info:
Offers open hot-spots, unlimited data to existing customers, and $10/month plans to low income families.
AT&T
Verizon Info:
No special offers, but following the FCC agreement.
Verizon page
Providers that do not work in the Huntsville area:
Comcast
Spectrum
Remember all of our campuses have internet that bleeds beyond the building, so if you sit or park your car outside, you should be able to access the internet to do your homework. **Please remember the social distancing rule and stay 6 feet away from others.
